_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Auxiliary yoke valves, flex lines, header valves, manifold piping, manifold ball valve, air actuated ball valves, manifold pressure gauge, low pressure switch, low temperature switch, CVPC ball valve,

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Ardent Mills, LC                                 Risk Management Program

Risk Management Plan (Subpart G)

Executive Summary (A§ 68.155)

Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy

It is the policy of facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68 and with the corresponding regulations under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Program. The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to  employees, the public and the environment. This objective will be accomplished by utilizing general good operating procedures, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers.

Management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

This facility utilizes processes raw wheat to produce flour. The raw materials used in the processes are wheat and chlorine gas. Support operations include a chlorine system, a quality control laboratory, and administrative offices.

One chemical is utilized at the facility, in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, RMP. Chlorine is added to enhance the color and baking performance of flour, especially that used in high?ratio cakes where the sugar level is over 120% like cake and cookies.
Chlorine interacts with flour increasing the permeability of the starch granule surface to give greater hydration, increased swelling and gelatinization of the starch, and consequently greater crumb strength. Chlorine addition achieves this end by disrupting the lipid?protein complex on the surface of the starch granule.
 
The reaction of raw flour and chlorine is complete within normal application rates of chlorine. There are no by?products or waste prod

ucts created in the reaction.  The end product is flour for human consumption. Chlorine used in the treatment of flour is a GRAS ingredient.
 
Worst-Case and Alternative-Release Scenarios

The Worst-Case Scenario for the Chester, Illinois location would be a damaged tank valve from the supplier. Each chlorine tank is independent of each other, therefore the loss of multiple tanks at the same time is not considered. This would result in the loss of 1 chlorine cylinder (liquified under pressure) contents of 2,000 pounds released over a duration of 10 minutes.
The tanks are located inside a storage room designed for chlorine storage, which acts as a passive mitigation technique and limits the release rate to 110 lbs/min. Due to chlorine being a chemical of interest, normal operating procedure only allows keycard access by qualified, trained, and CVI approved Ardent Mills personnel access to the room. Due to security measures, access doors are closed at all times during operations. A urban terrain type was selected as there are many trees, terrain features, and other obstacles in the immediate area.
RMP*Comp was used to determine the parameters of the chlorine release, which has a toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l. The predicted radius of the endpoint is 0.9 miles with 1.5 m/s wind speed with wind stability class F. This release is originating from the chlorine storage room, therefore it is used as the center point for the scenario.
MARPLOT was used to draw the worst case endpoint map.
The predicted the population within the 0.9 mile radius to be 546 people. The 2020 census data was obtained through the Missouri Census Data Center and used the circular area profile centered on the chlorine storage room.
Identified public receptors within toxic endpoint were identified as residences, an elementary school, and recreational areas. The identified environment receptor within the toxic endpoint is the Mississippi River.
 
Alternative Case Scenario
  
The Alternative Scenario for

the Chester, Illinois location would be a leak from a 3/8-inch copper flex line that connects the chlorine cylinder to the manifold. This scenario is more plausible than the worst-case scenario based on Ardent Mills operational experience concerning chlorine application systems. 
This scenario encompasses a damaged pigtail with a 3/8-hole expelling chlorine gas at 33.3 lbs. per minute for a duration of 3 minutes. 
The release would be inside the concrete block storage room designed for chlorine storage, which acts as a passive mitigation technique and limits the release rate. Additionally, a couple active mitigation measures are employed: emergency shut off actuators are installed on each chlorine cylinder in service on the tank valve. A chlorine gas detector is installed within the chlorine building and will automatically trigger shut off actuators to close each tank valve once a concentration of 4 ppm is detected. Due to chlorine being a chemical of interest, normal operating procedure only allows keycard access by qualified, trained, and CVI approved Ardent Mills personnel access to the building. Due to security measures, access doors are closed at all times during operations. 
An urban terrain type was selected as there are many trees, terrain features, and other obstacles in the immediate area. 
RMP*Comp was used to determine the parameters of the chlorine release, which has a toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l. The predicted radius of the endpoint is 0.1 miles with 3 m/s wind speed with wind stability class D and an air temperature of 77F. This release is originating from the chlorine storage building; therefore, it is used as the center point for the scenario. 
MARPLOT was used to draw the alternative-case endpoint map. The predicted the population within the 0.1 mile radius is 0. 
The 2020 census data was obtained through the Missouri Census Data Center and used the circular area profile centered on the chlorine storage room. 
No public receptors within toxic end

point were noted. The environmental receptor within toxic endpoint was noted to be the Mississippi River. 

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Employee participation in the release prevention program is encouraged and supported by management. Key personnel are responsible for conducting and implementing the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the chlorine system. Only trained and authorized employees or contractors are allowed to perform work on or adjacent to the chlorine system. 

The policy is to construct all new equipment, systems, and facilities in accordance with the most current building and safety codes, as well as conforming to the recommendations of the Chlorine Institute. This ensures the appropriate safety and release prevention systems are included from the beginning of each project. 

We are committed to providing appropriate training to all employees regarding the safety and health consideration of chlorine. Also, each new employee is provided comprehensive safety training during his or her initial orientation for the facility. In addition, we conduct annual safety training for maintenance and system operators specific to the handling and maintenance of the chlorine system. 

Five Year Accident History

We have not had a release of chlorine that has affected the public or the environment.

Emergency Response Program

Due to the proximity of local responders, we have instituted a "No Response" program. That is, direct contact with appropriate responders is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. System reviews and emergency action plans have been discussed and reviewed with the local responders and will be reviewed annually for the life of the process. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Ardent Mills, LLC and the Corbion (supplier) complete a thorough review of the chlorine systems each time a design change is implemented. The system is also evaluated each time the PHA is revised. We are
committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of these systems.
